author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Julianne Moore launches anti-gun violence group for celebs
text:
Charles Sykes/Charles Sykes/Invision/AP Julianne Moore, 54, said she believes the safety steps taken by the auto industry can serve as a model for stanching gun violence. Actress Julianne Moore has come out firing in support of ending gun violence.
The Oscar-winning star, horrified by the recent spate of high-profile shootings, is launching a group composed of celebrities dedicated to stemming the wave of gun crime.
Among the 79 bold-faced names who have already thrown their support behind Moore’s Everytown Creative Council are Alec Baldwin, Reese Witherspoon and Ellen DeGeneres.
THE NRA'S POLITICAL ARM: HOW MUCH THE GUN LOBBY GIVES YOUR ELECTED OFFICIALS
“As actors, we are citizens first so we believe in the Constitution and the Second Amendment,” Moore told PEOPLE magazine.
“But 92 percent of the people in the United States are in favor of background checks, too, so I don't feel like I'm in the minority. I definitely feel like I'm in the majority here.”
The group is affiliated with Everytown for Gun Safety, the organization founded by Mayor Bloomberg that aims to build support for stricter gun control.
Moore, 54, said she believes the safety steps taken by the auto industry can serve as a model for stanching gun violence.
Jamie McCarthy/Getty Images Kim Kardashian West is a member of the Everytown Creative Council. Kevin Winter/Getty Images Jennifer Lawrence has pledged to fight gun violence with the group. Lester Cohen/WireImage Conan O’Brien’s name also appears on the list of 79 celebrity supporters. Jason Merritt/Getty Images Aziz Ansari is also an Everytown Creative Council member. Previous Next Enlarge “For cars, you have to have training and you have to have a license, and you wear seat belts and we have airbags and we have all of these things in place that have reduced fatalities unbelievably," Moore says.
"And it was a totally unregulated industry at first. I feel like something that is very sensible and straight forward can be done also with guns."
Moore said she first got the idea for the group in the wake of the 2012 Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting that claimed the lives of 20 students and six adults.
Moore recalled shielding her 12-year-old daughter Liv from the first reports of the shooting.
But as they were decorating the family’s Christmas tree later in the day, Moore learned that Liv had gotten wind of the tragedy.
"She had her phone with her and she said, 'Mommy, did some kids get shot?'" Moore said.
"I was like, 'I've had it.' I said to my husband (director Bart Freundlich), 'I've got to do something. This is the one thing that I need to say something about. This is my responsibility as a parent.”
